item.title: Trump Urges Oil Companies to Speed Work in Venezuela
item.description: The president met with executives on a day when the U.S. seized another tanker carrying Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott, Emiliano Rodríguez Mega, Eric Schmitt and Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and members of his cabinet at a meeting with oil executives at the White House on Friday.

item.title: After President’s Capture, U.S. and Venezuela Explore Restoring Diplomatic Ties
item.description: The move embodied the contradictions and fast-changing nature of the two countries’ relationship.
item.dc:creator: Annie Correal
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: The United States Embassy in Caracas, Venezuela, in 2019.

item.title: GOP Seeks Some Distance From Trump as Midterm Election Year Opens
item.description: The vote to open a war powers debate, a pair of attempted veto overrides and a split on health care suggested a greater appetite among Republicans to challenge the president.
item.dc:creator: Carl Hulse
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times

item.title: Outside Prisons in Caracas, Venezuelans Anxiously Await Release of More Political Detainees
item.description: Venezuela’s interim government said it would release an “important number” of imprisoned people, but only nine have been confirmed freed.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: Family members awaiting the release of prisoners outside El Helicoide, a notorious prison in the center of Caracas, the Venezuelan capital, on Thursday.

item.title: Washington National Opera Is Leaving the Kennedy Center
item.description: The opera, which has performed at the arts center since 1971, was concerned about declines in attendance and donations during President Trump’s second term.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nagourney
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: Washington National Opera officials contend that exiting the Kennedy Center would also give it more control over programming decisions.

item.title: Trump Calls for 10 Percent Credit Card Interest Cap, After Killing Other Fee Limits
item.description: The president revived a campaign promise he has not actively pursued since taking office.
item.dc:creator: Stacy Cowley
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Trump Threatens to Take Greenland ‘the Hard Way’
item.description: The president continued to advance an imperialist vision of American foreign policy, where the U.S. can dominate neighboring countries “whether they like it or not.”
item.dc:creator: Chris Cameron
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump and members of his cabinet at the meeting with oil executives at the White House on Friday.

item.title: Iran Convulsed in Second Night of Nationwide Protests
item.description: Large marches against the government occurred despite an internet blackout and threats of a severe crackdown.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators marched in Tehran in an image taken from a social media post that was shared on Thursday.

item.title: A Look at Iran’s Antigovernment Protests
item.description: Protests have rocked Iran in recent weeks, and the country’s supreme leader has threatened to escalate a crackdown on demonstrators. Erika Solomon, our bureau chief for Iran and Iraq, discusses what’s fueling the protests with our senior writer Katrin Bennhold.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon, Katrin Bennhold, Christina Thornell, Christina Shaman, Parin Behrooz and Sanjana Varghese

item.title: What to Know About the Protests in Iran
item.description: Galloping inflation, a currency crisis and anger at the regime have fueled demonstrations across the country.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Leily Nikounazar
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Majid Asgaripour/Wana News Agency, via Reuters
item.media:description: A photograph released by Iranian state media showing shops in Tehran on Dec. 30 that were closed after protests.

item.title: New Cellphone Video Shows ICE Agent’s Perspective Before Minneapolis Shooting
item.description: The Department of Homeland Security posted a clip of the video on social media and said it was taken by the agent, who killed a 37-year-old woman in the shooting.
item.dc:creator: Mitch Smith, Hamed Aleaziz and Julie Bosman
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder/The New York Times
item.media:description: Officials blocked off an area near the shooting in Minneapolis on Wednesday.

item.title: Officials Identify Pair Shot by Border Patrol in Portland, Ore.
item.description: The two who were shot during a traffic stop are connected to the Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua, city and federal officials said. The shooting generated angry denunciations by local officials.
item.dc:creator: Anna Griffin and Jacey Fortin
item.media:credit: Jordan Gale for The New York Times
item.media:description: Police blocked off an area near where the victims of the shooting were found in Portland, Ore., on Thursday afternoon.

item.title: Trump Officials Reopen Thousands of Refugee Claims in Minnesota
item.description: The review comes as the federal government escalates its immigration enforcement in the state.
item.dc:creator: Madeleine Ngo
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Somali community in Minnesota, the largest in the country, has been the target of increased immigration enforcement.

item.title: How Our White House Photographer Finds New Angles on the Oval Office
item.description: Doug Mills, winner of three Pulitzers, sits, crawls and hoists cameras high in the air to bring viewers fresh perspectives. He was at it again this week during our marathon interview with President Trump.
item.dc:creator: Jodi Rudoren and Doug Mills
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: Doug Mills, left, photographing President Trump after an interview with The New York Times on Wednesday.

item.title: Volkswagen Suffers More Than Rivals From Auto Industry Woes
item.description: The German automaker’s sales in the United States plunged last year, hit by tariffs and the end of tax credits for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.category: Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks
item.media:credit: Jens Schlueter/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Electric vehicles at a Volkswagen plant in Dresden, Germany. The company is an extreme example of how difficult it has been for foreign automakers to cope in the U.S. car market.

item.title: Jobs Report Shows U.S. Hiring Slowed One Year Into Trump’s Second Term
item.description: As economists pointed to some of the president’s policies to explain the latest Labor Department data, White House aides sought to make the case for optimism in the new year.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm and Ben Casselman
item.category: White House Council of Economic Advisers
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.media:description: The December jobs tally showed how President Trump’s agenda may have impacted the economy during his first year back in office.

item.title: U.S. Hiring Continues at Modest Pace, but Weaknesses Are Evident
item.description: The unemployment rate fell in December, but job growth across 2025 was the lowest in five years.
item.dc:creator: Talmon Joseph Smith
item.category: White House Council of Economic Advisers
Center for Economic and Policy Research

item.title: With Missile Strike on Ukraine, Putin Delivers a Warning to Europe
item.description: A nuclear-capable missile fired into Ukraine near Poland sent a message to Europe days after its leaders agreed to postwar security guarantees, Russian analysts said.
item.dc:creator: Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage to an apartment building in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital, after a strike on Friday.

item.title: Hessy Levinsons Taft, Jewish Baby on Cover of Nazi Magazine, Dies at 91
item.description: Without her parents’ knowledge, her portrait was entered as a prank in a contest in 1935 to represent the ideal Aryan infant — and she won.
item.dc:creator: Michael S. Rosenwald

item.title: Mamdani Responds Cautiously After the Police Kill 2 People in One Night
item.description: Mayor Zohran Mamdani did not call the shootings justified, but said New York Police officers were placed in “incredibly difficult and dangerous circumstances.”
item.dc:creator: Maia Coleman and Maria Cramer
item.media:credit: Anna Watts for The New York Times
item.media:description: On Friday, New York Mayor Zohran Mamdani repeated plans for a new agency that would respond to mental health crises in the wake of two fatal shootings by the police.

item.title: Mamdani Condemns Slurs and Pro-Hamas Chant at Heated Queens Protest
item.description: Pro-Palestinian and pro-Israel demonstrators hurled threats at each other outside an event promoting real estate sales in Jerusalem. The mayor said those actions had “no place in our city.”
item.dc:creator: Liam Stack and Nate Schweber
item.category: Agudath Israel of America;World Agudath Israel
item.media:credit: Mimi d’Autremont for The New York Times
item.media:description: The protesters squared off on Thursday night across police barricades in front of a synagogue in Kew Gardens Hills, a neighborhood with a sizable population of Orthodox Jews.

item.title: Mamdani’s First Big Move to Help Renters Is Dealt a Blow by Court
item.description: Summit Properties USA won an auction on Friday to buy more than 5,000 apartments out of bankruptcy from the Pinnacle Group despite City Hall’s efforts to intervene.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Union of Pinnacle Tenants protested Summit Properties USA’s effort to buy Pinnacle Group properties on Thursday. Both companies appear to have many reported housing violations.

item.title: Trump Is Threatening Greenland and Europe
item.description: Any attempt to seize Greenland from Denmark would fatally undermine the world’s most successful military alliance.
item.dc:creator: James Kirchick
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times

item.title: This Is Trump’s One Small Trick to Destroy American Democracy
item.description: The president is claiming borderless license to turn on his perceived enemies, both foreign and domestic.
item.dc:creator: Lydia Polgreen

item.title: I.C.C. Judges Denounce Effect of Trump’s Sanctions
item.description: President Trump’s retaliation against top officials at the International Criminal Court has shut them out of American services and made even routine daily tasks a challenge.
item.dc:creator: Marlise Simons
item.media:credit: Peter Dejong/Associated Press
item.media:description: The International Criminal Court in The Hague. U.S. sanctions come at a time when the court is investigating claims of atrocities in Afghanistan, Libya, Myanmar, Sudan, Ukraine and Venezuela, as well as Gaza.

item.title: Rare Comic Introducing Superman Sells Privately for $15 Million
item.description: The copy of Action Comics No. 1, published in 1938, was stolen from the actor Nicolas Cage in 2000 and recovered more than a decade later.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Ziegler
item.media:credit: Andrew Wilson/Metropolis Collectibles Inc, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A copy of the comic that introduced Superman in 1938. Fewer than 100 copies are known to exist.

item.title: Joel Habener, Whose Research Led to Weight-Loss Drugs, Dies at 88
item.description: His discovery of the protein fragment GLP-1 was crucial in the development of Ozempic, Wegovy and other blockbuster obesity and diabetes treatments.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata

item.title: Minnesota Woman Dies After Shark Bite in U.S. Virgin Islands, Authorities Say
item.description: People at the beach went to the woman’s rescue and helped her ashore, the authorities said, but she died at a hospital.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk
item.media:credit: Erika P. Rodríguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The woman was at a beach on the island of St. Croix when a shark bit her, the authorities said.
